events.description: Bitcoin dropped below $73,000 in early February, reaching its lowest levels since November 2024.
US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent testified regarding the Treasury's authority over digital assets.

facts.fact_text: Bitcoin dropped below $73,000 in early February.

evidences.evidence_text: Bitcoin dropped below $73,000 in early February

facts.fact_text: US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent stated the US government would not bail out cryptocurrency.

evidences.evidence_text: US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said the US government would not bail out the cryptocurrency

facts.fact_text: Bessent stated he has no authority to buy bitcoin or other digital assets.

evidences.evidence_text: Bessent answered that he has no such authority

facts.fact_text: Bitcoin is down more than 40% from its October peak.

evidences.evidence_text: The world’s largest cryptocurrency is now down more than 40% from its October peak

claims.claim_text: The bitcoin selloff could deepen and cause lasting damage to companies with large holdings.
claims.author: Michael Burry

evidences.evidence_text: investor Michael Burry warning the selloff could deepen and inflict lasting damage on companies that amassed large holdings over the past year

claims.claim_text: Bitcoin is a purely speculative asset and has failed as a debasement hedge compared to gold.
claims.author: Michael Burry

evidences.evidence_text: He argued that bitcoin has been exposed as a purely speculative asset and has failed to serve as a debasement hedge comparable to gold and other precious metals

evidence.evidence_text: Bitcoin dropped below $73,000... after US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said the US government would not bail out the cryptocurrency
warning the selloff could deepen and inflict lasting damage on companies that amassed large holdings
the US government would not bail out the cryptocurrency
